option_cards.title: Drop off as household hazardous waste

actions.label: Info
actions.text: Button batteries should be properly disposed of as household hazardous waste at the following drop-off locations. These batteries contain heavy metals which can be harmful to human health and the environment if not disposed of properly. Always tape button batteries with clear tape prior to dropping them off for recycling. Batteries should NEVER be included in curbside recycling or trash, as they can be highly flammable if not handled safely. You can learn more about battery dangers, proper storage and recycling at Larimer County's battery recycling webpage. View the Battery Recycling Guide. View information about business hazardous waste disposal options.

actions.label: Info

option_cards.title: Drop off as household hazardous waste

actions.label: Info
actions.text: Lithium Ion batteries can be disposed of at the following drop-off locations. All Batteries must be taped on the ends with clear tape before being dropped off at these locations for the safety of staff and visitors. Lithium Ion batteries should NEVER be included in curbside recycling or trash, as they can be highly flammable if not handled safely. These batteries have caused multiple fires at recycling facilities in recent years. No matter whether a battery is rechargeable or not, it is safest to dispose of it as household hazardous waste. You can learn more about battery dangers, proper storage and recycling at Larimer County's battery recycling webpage. View the Battery Recycling Guide. View information about business hazardous waste disposal options.

actions.label: Info
actions.text: Compostable serving ware and dishware, along with other compostable containers, should be thrown away in the trash or composted through a commercial composting company. Compostable products, like those made from corn or bagasse, are NOT recyclable and should never be included in curbside recycling or taken to recycling drop-off locations. This includes plates, bowls, cubs, silverware, straws, napkins, and other serving ware labeled as compostable. They are intended to break down when added to a commercial composting system. Backyard composting systems and other small residential composting systems do not get hot enough to break down compostable serving ware.

actions.label: Info
actions.text: Food scraps can be composted in backyard composting systems or collected by a subscription composting service (see options below). For more food savings and compost tips, see below. More tips: savethefood.org ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Compost What's Left Some food scraps are unavoidable. Composting keeps them out of the landfill and helps improve soil health. Five easy steps to compost at home: Set up a bin or spaceChoose a bin or outdoor spot about 3'x3'x3'. Keep it dampCompost should feel like a wrung-out sponge. Use your compostAfter about a year, if your compost smells like soil, it's ready for your garden, lawn or houseplants. Sift out any large pieces and return them to the pile to keep composting. More tips: Eco-Cycle Composting Guide Boulder County Backyard Composting Local Info for Fort Collins The Fort Collins Nuisance Code allows compost piles at single- and two-family homes if they're maintained to prevent pests (Sec. actions.label: Info
actions.text: Reusable quantities of liquid paint in good condition can be dropped off to Larimer County's Hazardous Waste "Drop ‘N' Swap" Facility. Latex paints and other water-based paints can be taken to the following drop of locations. Recycling at these locations is free of charge through Paint Care Colorado. One way to identify paint as latex (water-based) or oil-based is by reading the cleanup instructions on the can. If water can be used for cleanup, the paint is latex paint. If solvents, such as paint thinner or mineral spirits must be used, the paint is oil-based. Highly flammable paints, such as epoxy base, stains, lacquers, varnishes, or shellacs, or paints containing heavy metals, such as cadmium or lead, must be taken to the Larimer County Household Hazardous Waste Collection Facility. Liquid paint should never be disposed of in the trash. Paint should also never be poured down the drain or dumped on the ground. When poured down the drain, many of the chemicals in paint will bypass wastewater treatment or septic systems and may contaminate lakes, streams, or ground water.

actions.label: Info
actions.text: Brown crinkle paper, like that used for packing and gifts, is recyclable but should not go into your curbside bin. You can drop it off at a recycling center that accepts it; place the shredded paper loose (not bagged) in the mixed paper bin. Do NOT include shredded crinkle paper in your curbside recycle bin. The paper literally falls through the cracks in the machinery at the sorting facility and will not be recycled.
